Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the lack of ventilators in the country when President Trump took office, stating that the cupboards were completely empty.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there were actually 16,660 ventilators immediately available for use in the Strategic National Stockpile when the federal government began deploying them.
Understate: The claim understates the number of ventilators distributed during the pandemic, stating that none were bought by the Trump administration, when in fact, 10,640 ventilators were distributed.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or data to back up the assertion that there were very few ventilators in the country when President Trump took office.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the lack of ventilators was solely the responsibility of the previous administration and that President Trump had to refill the stockpile.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider the alternative explanation that the concerns about ventilator shortages in March were due to the rapid spread of COVID-19 and the uncertainty surrounding the pandemic, rather than a lack of action or preparation by the previous administration.
